qas.question: What term is used to refer to the period from 1750 to 1820?
What years are termed the Renaissance period?
What years are termed the Baroque period?
Classical music is rooted in what kind of tradition?
Classical music is rooted the the traditions of what kind of music?
What is the period from 1750 to 1820 called?
What time period is known at the common practice period?

context: Classical music is art music produced or rooted in the traditions of <a4_0><a5_0>Western<a5_0/> music<a4_0/>, including both liturgical (religious) and secular music. While a similar term is also used to refer to the period from 1750 to 1820 (<a0_0><a6_0>the Classical period<a6_0/><a0_0/>), this article is about the broad span of time from roughly the 11th century to the present day, which includes the Classical period and various other periods. The central norms of this tradition became codified <a7_0>between 1550 and 1900<a7_0/>, which is known as the common practice period. The major time divisions of classical music are as follows: the early music period, which includes the Medieval (500–1400) and the Renaissance (<a1_0>1400–1600<a1_0/>) eras; the Common practice period, which includes the Baroque (<a2_0>1600–1750<a2_0/>), Classical (1750–1820), and <a3_0>Romantic<a3_0/> eras (1804–1910); and the 20th century (1901–2000) which includes the modern (<a8_0>1890–1930<a8_0/>) that overlaps from the late 19th-century, the high modern (mid 20th-century), and contemporary or postmodern (1975–2015) eras.[citation needed]
